description: First attested in its present form in 1650–1660: From Middle English hircyne, from Latin hircīnus (“of a goat”, “goat-scented”); equivalent to hircus (“a male goat”) + -īnus (“-ine”). Cognate with French hircin. Compare caprine, haedine.

adjectives.description: hircine (comparative more hircine, superlative most hircine)

entries.meaning: (book word, not comparable) Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of goats.
examples: Many[plants of family Hypericaceae] are objects of ornament, but they are little cultivated because they have frequently a disagreeable hircine odour.

entries.meaning: Possessed of an odour reminiscent of goats.
(mineralogy) A fossil amorphous resin which, when burnt, gives off a pungent, hircinous aroma.
